featuredReview.headline: MSTR software engineer
featuredReview.pros:
* MSTR HQ is in a prime location in Tysons VA, steps away from shopping mall and restaurants
* The BI software has a great solid architecture/foundation
* Young & Vibrant working force in the engineering department
* Beautiful and bright office
* Good work/life balance
* Great team members who are brilliant and highly educated

I think the company does a great job in taking of its employees by offering affordable/great health insurance plans, the gym, free lunch/breakfast activities that happen occasionally. Although I don't know other people's compensation, I am happy with mine.
featuredReview.cons:
MSTR is a tech company, but from what I see, the engineering department is pretty much run by mostly non-technical people including the CTO, product owners, etc. Partly because of this reason, the company or products lack innovation badly. Most engineers I know work on fixing defects and bugs for 80 - 90% of their work time, this is necessary for delivering quality products, however, for the remaining of their time, engineers work on features that customers may never need/ask. Many features are just plain dumb and the reason why they are created is because the product owners can't keep his people idling while getting paid.

the legacy code smells and feels like a bucket of dynamite - if you change something without knowing the big picture, the entire system may crash -- boom!!!

From my experience, engineers are not encouraged to be innovative and they are **told** what defects/features they should work on from each sprint. The only opportunity I see as innovative is the hackathon that happens only ONCE a year. Compared to other companies I know, Facebook has 6- 8 hackathons a year! 

MSTR should encourage its engineers to think out of the box, the product owners have no idea what makes a great software. 

Favoritism is another problem I see on a daily basis, if the PO favors someone, s/he will give that person a fat bonus, which is quite unfair to those who keep their heads down and working hard.

I see no clear career path within the company either.

featuredReview.headline: Gulfstream: Honest, Ethical, and Awesome
featuredReview.pros:
Excellent and Honest Recruiters: 
My Gulfstream recruiter was so intent on bringing me into the fold that he asked me over and over to give notice at my previous job. I remember feeling so flattered. I gave notice as requested but then the strangest thing happened…My recruiter called me the day before my scheduled move to inform me that my background check hadn’t cleared. The recruiter then told me that Gulfstream would not move me until my background check cleared. I was unemployed and living on savings for more than a month. Honestly, that recruiter was such a magnanimous and remarkable fellow. I still have such fond memories of him.

Impeccable Ethics: 
I spoke with some colleagues who started at Gulfstream around the same time as me. It turned out that recruiters were doing the same thing to other folks that they did to me. There were some legitimate issues with Gulfstream’s background service provider at time (really, there were some problems with the provider). I love how Gulfstream did not bother to inform any of the job candidates. I still marvel at Gulfstream’s unprecedented ethics while acquiring and holding onto to new hires. I actually seek to emulate those same ethics in my daily life.
featuredReview.cons: Okay, I’m going to cut the sarcasm for a brief moment. There actually are some good departments to work in at Gulfstream. I had some colleagues who managed to find fulfillment at Gulfstream. Unfortunately, not everyone can be that lucky. Do your homework and know your worth. If you plan on making a career at Gulfstream in the bad areas, then keep your head down, do as your told, do not try to improve processes, and DO NOT complain to management. Knowing the corporate handbook rules will not help you as those rules apparently only apply to the proletariat. Middle and upper management take complaints very seriously…in that they will seriously intimidate, micromanage, and outright lie until you shut up. Alright, let’s get back into sarcasm mode…

featuredReview.pros:
Compensation Model:  6 month up-front signing bonuses; lifetime monthly residuals; portfolio ownership; Easy to understand comp plan;Hasn't changed in over 20 years.
Training: Ongoing and consistent with best practices in our industry; All tools to succeed are available - Territory Manager, Division Manager, VP of Sales have always been accessible and willing to help in the growth of their sales team; online trainings and resources; great Sales Support team to contact.
Culture:  The leadership that I report to have always maintained a positive and encouraging attitude...not something I was used to at other places I have worked.  Additionally, others sales reps who have no financial incentive to help me, have played an integral part of my success at Heartland.
featuredReview.cons: Con for most people is that it is 100% commission and starting without a book of business.  A pro to this con is our lifetime residuals.  Even on a slow month, I was able to pay my mortgage and several other bills with my monthly residual check alone.

featuredReview.headline: Finance Leader - US
featuredReview.pros: I genuinely like working here a lot! The management is down to earth, polite, and is there to serve the company. There exists almost limitless opportunities to join in on new projects and initiatives. It is very easy to make continuous improvements--the vast majority of the time, we're encouraged to work smarter, not harder with almost no red tape.
featuredReview.cons: The org structure has relatively few titles and it seems like there is almost no standardization in how employees obtain these titles. When I call corporate, I have the choice to talk to a finance manager with 15 years of experience in our field with knowledge abound, or a director that has one year of experience and can provide almost no higher level direction. There are also very few women leaders in finance, and I'm not sure if I have met any minority leaders that were not Asian.  It's almost like no one gives any thought to diversity whatsoever. It's not discouraged, but definitely not a priority even on the lowest level. Also, as you might imagine, the pay is all over the place, but generally very LOW unless you are very new. The executives just gave themselves a base pay increase, and I think they should cascade that to some other areas in the company since stock options are worthless and bonuses have not materialized in the last few years.

featuredReview.headline: While there is no perfect company, Guidewire is about as close as you are going to get.
featuredReview.pros:
While there is no perfect company, Guidewire is about as close as you are going to get.  We run into challenges like every company does--some internal, some external.  But when your entire organization, not just the executives, are rational and highly intelligent, it makes solving those problems a lot easier and faster.    

The long-term trajectory of Guidewire is amazingly strong and senior leadership, from the person I report to all they way to our CEO, is truly exceptional.  The group consists of quite possibly the most humble, rational group of leaders that could be collected.  This is a unique place to work.
featuredReview.cons: It's tough to articulate cons that are unique to Guidewire.   For example, if you are in a role at Guidewire that requires heavy travel, does that force you to constantly plan and adjust to achieve work-life balance?  Of course--but that's true of any company.

featuredReview.headline: RN General Medicine
featuredReview.pros:
Awesome coworkers that have your back/are very helpful

Self-scheduling (could be both pro and con)
Alternate holidays (again could be both pro and con)
Opportunity to join committees throughout the hospital
Pediatrics, only hospital in the Cincinnati area you can be in Peds unless you are in the NICU at the area hospitals
featuredReview.cons:
Company is working towards a Lean structure - cutting benefits previously offered that used to make them competitive but now are just mediocre.
-Cutting costs to save up for another building when they can't fill the last one they expanded on (Liberty campus).
-Increasing patient to nurse ratios to again cut budgets to save up for new building.
-Reducing pensions previously offered.
-Pay to park in the garages on-site from your paycheck
-Hospital boasts about offering support for furthering education, but they're selective on what they will do tuition reimbursement for (will not help pay for certain NP programs for the last couple years). Also tries to say they're competitive pay but still under-par for most area hospitals.
-If you work third shift don't expect any of the extra perks that the hospital offers day shift - pizza days for high census? all ordered same time of day so night shift's has been sitting out all day and no longer edible. Free 15 minute neck massages during nurse's week? only offered noon-3pm.

featuredReview.headline: Solid Company
featuredReview.pros: Choice Hotels is a solid company. It's constantly pushing to grow the business. They have a strong HR department that plans company events and a good matching program when it comes to your 401K. In general, it's run well. Still mainly male in the C-suite though. It's definitely a demanding corporate environment, but with a general friendly atmosphere.
featuredReview.cons: They are constantly restructuring and having layoffs.  They don't promote people, even when they are performing well, and therefore they ultimately leave for other opportunities, which ultimately costs the company. They work in silos and departments don't share information with each other, which also hurts the business. Part of this is a structural issue, part of this is probably endemic at any large company, and part of it is human nature. Very political atmosphere. They are risk averse when it comes to marketing innovation, yet they pride themselves on being innovative. Too much empahsis on driving bookings vs. long term thinking about brand building. Leadership lacks vision and creativity and has a myopic view on driving revenue in the short term. They are innovative in many ways, but conservative in general.  It's a solid company with good people, but environment is changing and has lost it's sense of congeniality.

featuredReview.headline: Incredible Internship Experience
featuredReview.pros:
They truly invest an incredible amount of time and effort into creating a phenomenal internship experience. Competitive intern wages (for my field), solid relocation package ($2500-$3000 depending on where you resided), mentorship, good projects. 

I never felt like I was forgotten or expendable when I interned at Akamai this past summer. Within the first week, I had felt that I had fully integrated into my team (which held a welcome dinner on the first day of work!), and throughout the rest of the summer, worked on a number of projects that were relevant to my team's work whilst simultaneously gave me a good degree of freedom to expand my knowledge base of my field's work. 

All interns are matched with a mentor, and as someone who still floundering a little bit and unsure of the direction that my career is going to go, my mentor (as well as other members of my team) helped assuage my fears, and guide me in the work that I was doing, and could invest in for the future.
featuredReview.cons: I know that my experience was incredible, but that didn't necessarily translate to all other intern experiences. I don't have much to say here, from my point of view.

featuredReview.pros:
I am so grateful to have been a part of the Bare Minerals team. I was at my boutique part time and I needed a full time position but to this day I stand behind the product and guarantee it is THE BEST skincare and make-up in terms of quality, effectiveness, and integrity. 

The company culture is respectful, and has a great integrity. The make-up has  amazing skincare benefits. The skincare has precious, rare, natural ingredients that hydrate and revitalize the skin. My favorite skincare product is the skinlongevity serum. Skinlongevity is an awarding winning serum that unveils your healthiest skin through unparalleled hydration and melanin regulation featuring blue ginger extract. 

The make-up features excellent flawless foundations as well as eye and lip products. Color selection is fabulous and universally flattering.  From fair to deeper skin tones Bare Minerals has complexion, eye, and lip products for YOU! 

Bare Minerals products are not tested on animals and they’re safe to use for pregnant women. NO OTHER prestige skincare and make-up brand has such a quality and natural product services from vitamins and minerals that will not only not harm you but actually improve the health of your skin. 

I had an incredible team. Our boutique had a wonderful atmosphere and we were all like family and I miss them all and hold our memories dear to my heart.
featuredReview.cons: A lot of boutiques don’t offer full time positions except for upper management but a part- time beauty advisor is a great position for college students who are make-up and skincare enthusiasts looking to be part of an amazing company.

featuredReview.headline: Read the review
featuredReview.pros:
I started my career at Esurance and have transitioned roles during my time. I have had the opportunity to define my interests and have the support of my managers and coworkers to explore them and enhance my skills. It's more investment than I could have expected. For many associates, they are building strong foundations for their careers here, and many times, growing their careers here.

My experience with work/life balance has been good here. I work my own schedule, I never take work home (physically or mentally), and I know this is pretty true across the board. I think more intense teams like IT probably have it a little more tough, but we're an online insurance company. They have a lot of responsibility in keeping us running. 

We have company values that really resonate across the company. Sure they can come off cheesy, but I have coworkers who live and breath our values. And that's pretty awesome. It connects them to their work and drives them on. Plus, we have a culture the celebrates our diversity. We have employee resource groups that celebrate and encourage the development of traditionally underrepresented groups in the work place. I think that's pretty cool!
featuredReview.cons:
The leadership of the company needs to be open to hearing from the associates. Their concerns and insight. And I think that our company leadership want that, but somewhere along the chain of command, people are discouraged from speaking up. It's not about fear of retaliation. I think overtime associates have just heard "we can't do that", "that's just the way it is", or have been told that it's not a good idea to give feedback. To be fair, some people are just complaining, and their attitudes ruin it for everyone. But there are many who do have good ideas who should be heard and encouraged to speak.

In regards to benefits, if you're single, we have pretty good benefits. I think with the current state of health care in the country right now, no company has great health benefits right now, unless you're Google or Apple. I wish it was better, but hey, I'm insured and that's what matters.

9. Believes in integrity!!! <~ Another big plus

9. Won't get raises... :(
10. Not enough hours for sales associates which hinders hiring and whether they stay or leave ...

featuredReview.headline: Good dedicated accounts for rookies

I started on the dollar tree account out of Savannah Georgia; it was a lot of work hand unloading the trailer but good pay.  I went OTR solo,  that sucked.  Teams probably earn most of the miles and loads with this company.   After a few weeks OTR I made a quick phone call and that day I was given 5,000 dollars to relocate to Indiana to be on a dedicated Wal-Mart account, home daily, earning a base pay salary of 950 a week.  Not bad for a first year rookie. ..Safety is big with this company, I recommend it to anyone starting out.  Trucks are good and new, well maintained.   I've heard they may have changed their idle policy but the temperature based idle policy was a huge downside and enough of a reason to not go back there.

featuredReview.headline: Amazing mission, people and products with increasingly competitive benefits and perks
featuredReview.pros: The mission and culture are really motivating. Illumina is filled with bright, passionate people who care and are typically humble and nice. The CEO is focused on building leaders, leveraging culture to differentiate us, and building products that will revolutionize genomics and its role in healthcare and medicine.  Lots of challenging and interesting work and projects to tackle. People work really hard and it can be a lot of hours but typically leaders give enough flexibility to help balance personal and professional needs. Benefits are good but not great, although the company offers a nice amount of PTO and holidays as well as solid perks and campus amenities.
featuredReview.cons: Illumina is figuring out how to keep its start-up level of innovation and collaboration while also maturing into a large company. That transformation isn't easy and seems like we're becoming too hierarchical, which honestly deceases empowerment and ultimately speed of decision-making - typical growing pains for a company growing and scaling really quickly.  It feels like we're chasing too many markets at times and not being disciplined and focused on our biggest opportunities. Even though the restricted stock program is nice, the 401k is really weak and the bonus program is highly volatile.

featuredReview.headline: Good company on the verge of GREATNESS!
featuredReview.pros:
- New CEO, New Head of Human Capital, the future is here! Huge push to help remedy some of the long standing obstacles that happen in most growing companies. Firm wide focus on training and development to give us a place we can really grow a lifetime career. 
- PRIVATE COMPANY - We don't have 10,000 employees or shareholders we need to think of. Our clients come first, always, and employees and innovation come as close runners up. 
- A+ Benefits - $0 come out of my paycheck for medical and dental premiums (at previous employers this used to cost me $400 a month). Fisher matches 50% of my 401k  contributions - This year they have given me $7,000 towards my 401k so far!
- The people - Not your average "investment firm". Youthful firm full of excited individuals who are looking to learn and grow. Collaboration is at the forefront of everything we do. You come in and have an instant network of peers and mentors to help you navigate problems, celebrate success and give you valuable feedback.
featuredReview.cons: - Schedule Flexibility - The hours are 7-5 or 6:30-4:30 for most roles (Sales and IC are on 8 hour shifts). The work is done 100% in office (no work from home). I worry that when the time comes for me to start a family, this is going to be hard to juggle. There are plenty of people here who make it work, and the schedule + the benefits make for a great place to be while raising kids. However for me it is a constant question I have in my mind.

featuredReview.headline: Great Culture and Product
featuredReview.pros:
I had left a few years ago, but working at FAST was still my best experience in any work environment. I fully attribute this to the PM at the project and my team lead. They were exceptional: caring, intelligent, and great problem solvers. The company does care about the employees - it's very clear. The work itself may not always be extremely challenging, but I was never bored at work. The people that are promoted to a lead role deserve it and are hard workers.

In response to the reviews mentioning that the skills don't translate over from this job to another: From someone who has left and gone to other jobs, if you're looking for a specific software or class to teach you a skillset, no you won't be learning 'transferable' skills. However, you are still learning VB.NET, SQL, and client-facing exposure. You are also learning implementation cycles as well as good coding practices. New hires that look at FAST software and say it's not good... It is worse in many places; it's the best I've worked with...  Look past the 'proprietary' software and understand the usage of it. Fast's version control is excellent. Learn the concepts of the tools and I would wager you will be shocked at the similarities and how much skill is indeed 'transferable'. 

When I was relocated, I felt the overall process was very easy. People come and pack/pick up your furniture/items/car. You take a flight to the new state and stay in a hotel which is paid for until your items are shipped. If they hold your belongings, you will have to pay out of pocket.
featuredReview.cons: For me it was the traveling aspect, but this works for some people.

featuredReview.headline: Chemical Engineering Internship
featuredReview.pros: Air Products is really good with helping you figure out where you fit best in the company. Moving around the company is encouraged and this is one of the only places where engineers dont just have to work an engineering job to make the company better. Air Products has a really helpful CDP program (Career Development Program) where you go through a three year process when you get hired to determine where you fit best. You switch locations and positions every year for three years and then at the end you can choose where you want to start off officially in the company. All the people I met there were extremely nice and pleasant to work with! Pay is very good and I really enjoyed this company overall! They give their interns meaningful projects and want you to contribute and innovate new ideas for the company! They treat you like a full time employee which I found to be very nice.
featuredReview.cons: Recently got a new CEO and cuts are being made to reorganize the company. Stability in the job isn't as good as it is made out to be, at least for the next year or so until everything is figured out. Location of Air Products HQ in Allentown, PA is not the best, kind of boring and not much to do.

featuredReview.headline: Finally, A Company That Feels Like Home
featuredReview.pros:
After 15 years in my career, I've finally found a company that truly fits 96% if not more of my needs, wants and desires. It is the perfect place for me in my life right now, professionally and personally. I used to think that a job could only be but so good -- that it could only satisfy two of the three major requirements (pay, people and project). My husband says that he learned in business school that you will, in fact, only ever get two of the three. However, I have found all three at Glassdoor. A great salary, funny/hard-working people and a project or work product that challenges me every day and gives me the autonomy I've been looking for.

It's a senior start-up, as I like to say. Glassdoor has the nimbleness of a start-up with none of the uncertainty. It has the professional polish of a large company without the politics or bureaucracy. It's a great place for those who know what they want and have the drive, passion and mid-career experience to make it happen.
featuredReview.cons:
As a member of the marketing organization, I don't experience many of the downsides that others might. Overall it's a very strong organization. However, to provide balance, here are the areas that need improvement:
-Clear focus on business objectives and resources. While there is so much to do with the product and in the space, Glassdoor is only 750 people. Prioritization is key. To do everything we want to do, we'll have to either focus on the 80-20 rule more, or hire more people.

-Location. I love working on the waterfront, but the commute is hard for 85% of the company in Mill Valley. A larger SF office with opportunities to work from there would be great not only for current staff but for our recruitment and retention efforts.

-People of Color. No need to beat around the bush, I'm not talking about "diversity." I'm referring to actual people of color in our ranks. We need more. We have diversity of thought, gender, socio-economic status, etc. However, Glassdoor truly struggles with hiring and retaining people of color. It's no longer okay to say that we're not as big as our contemporaries and, therefore, cannot put the emphasis on hiring people of color. It's imperative to our innovation and growth that we invest in racially diverse communities.

featuredReview.headline: Fun environment, limited for women, issues in sales
featuredReview.pros: Very nice people! They mean well and for the most part, very workable. If you are in an office there are great perks like gourmet food, lots of company fun and events, good culture. Great benefits. Bonus plans. Unlimited PTO. I enjoyed my time here and feel it was a great place to have on the resume.
featuredReview.cons:
Upward mobility for women is desperately lacking. They were just voted a great place to work for women. Why?  Because of a generous maternity policy, I would assume.  They didn't even mention women in their write-up about it which is exactly appropriate for the situation. The ranking is smoke and mirrors. There are no women in the C suite and the smartest VP's leave for the C suite elsewhere. There are lots of men who think they are really smart, and most of them are, but the smartest leaders are the ones who admit and act upon diverse solutions. 
There are women on the service teams and a few other departments who are promoted and very few "friends of the family" who they know they can control. Women in sales who have moved up recently had another layer placed over their head. They are now pretty much at the same level they were but with even less power because of the additional male-dominated team put above them. Talk about a rock and a hard place. 

Tech teams are untouchable even when a client has valid issues. This creates unbelievable expectations on the sales team to keep the client happy, with no power, while your quota and livelihood is tied to this insanity.

Everything operates in a shroud of mystery. They intentionally keep departments away from each other and their favorite word to a client need is "no". Be prepared for more NO than you have ever experienced before. It took me 4 months to figure out pricing because there is no pricing. It is "what can you get out of your customers" which is why I think this shroud exists and quite frankly, working.

Bonus plans are paid instead of commissions.  In the beginning, this seems cool, until you realize that for the amount of product you are selling, it is very subpar to industry standards, you can't help but realize you are being bilked.  Especially when there were bonus bumps after ample service but they seem to have been done away with that with recent management changes. Last note on bonus over the commission structures that most salespeople are accustom to. Commissions are protected by law, bonus payouts are not.  This means that as soon as you sell something on commission, you are owed that commission by law.  Bonus is never required to be paid out, they will use this to their advantage and not yours.

Base Pay: good when you 1st evaluate it.  Once you get in you realize they are paying less experienced, worse performers, more. My assessment is because they are male. You are "forbidden to discuss pay rates", though by law, you are allowed to and it is illegal for them to tell you that you can fire you for it.  Look it up! They can be heavily fined for this practice if someone decides to go after them.  Hello Lilly Ledbetter!

Unlimited PTO:  Again this looks great on the surface. Who wouldn't want that!?! It is actually a catch 22.  It is very enticing until you want to use it. When I put in for less PTO than I had taken the year before unlimited PTO change, I was chastised for abusing the policy. It all comes down to your manager.  Additionally, if you accrue PTO, when you leave, they have to pay that out to you.  They do not with an unlimited plan.

Goal setting: An unspoken mystery of how they produce your goal for the quarter.  Supposedly with "algorithms" and other voodoo magic. The rumor is the finance team does it- like they have any clue what your clients will be up to that quarter. Then it is handed to the sale managers where they have the liberty to adjust the number to each member of their team. (I'm not sure even they know how the initial numbers are produced. ) Soooo the top performers are almost always getting exceedingly high expectations because they work themselves to death to hit them and the not so top performers barely grow their territories. At the end of the quarter, both top, and not so top, are paid almost the same bonus with a few percentage point changes to make it less obvious... It's awesome... yeah right.  
Sales industry norms are that teams hit quota 65-75% of the time. Anything more is too easy, anything less, too hard. At Indeed, if you don't hit quota 100% of the time, you risk going "on plan". Another recent development since management change this past year. They use this form of punishment arbitrarily.  If they like you and you keep hitting 90-95% of your goal, your cool.  No worries.  If they don't like you and you hit 95-99%, you could be in trouble or made to feel unwanted. Which as salespeople know is usually the same end result. Recently, a manager really liked their employee but senior management decided it was their time to go.  He intruded on the relationship until the employee had no choice but to leave. Good times!

Work/life balance: If you let it, Indeed will work you to death. If you don't care as much and everyone really likes you, you can live it up fairly cush and just keep hanging. I worked so hard, and everyone really liked me, and I really liked them, but I just couldn't do another year of it. They pushed me until I broke, because I cared, exceeded my goals, and was the positive life of the party.  Unfortunately, as soon as you start to feel less taken care of by your employer than you are taking care of them, it's hard to get back from burnt.

featuredReview.headline: A GREAT COMPANY THAT VALUES AND CARES ABOUT THEIR EMPLOYEES
featuredReview.pros:
First and foremost, I'd like to start off by stating that it is very rare that I take the time to post any type of reviews, comments, or any other piece of information online.  But I must admit, on this occasion I felt very compelled and wanted to take a moment and share with everyone who reads this review, how awesome it is to work for an employer who truly does care and values the well-being, safety, and success of its employees. That employer I speak of is Ultimate Medical Academy Online in Tampa Florida.  As you all must know from recent news, that the area of Tampa Bay experienced a serious and dangerous hurricane in the past week, that being Hurricane Irma.  During this time of preparation prior and after the storm’s passing, Ultimate Medical Academy went above and beyond in being as accommodating as you would want any company to be by not only providing several support services, but also allowing us to take the necessary time outside of the work place to be with our loved ones and do what was necessary in order to prepare for this Monster storm’s arrival.  

After several days of recover from the storm’s aftermath, it was time to return to work.  Upon return, Ultimate Medical Academy provided us all with a pretty amazing lunch spread, not only for our first day back, but we were informed that we would have lunch provided for the remainder of the week!  Pretty awesome stuff don’t you think?  Wait, it gets better!!  Aside from the lunch that was provided for us, we were also informed that we were all being compensated for the regularly scheduled time that we had missed due to the storm.  Yes, that is correct!  No hours needed to be taken from our PTO time.  Ultimate Medical Academy was compensating us as if we had worked those scheduled hours even though we were not physically at work, working. What company does that?!  And for several days mind you!   I have never worked for a company who not only values our success and growth as professionals, but also values our well-being, our family’s well-being, and our safety.  For those of you who are new to the company, feel grateful and appreciate that you work for a pretty awesome organization.  For those of you who are still questioning whether you should apply for possible consideration to be a part of our organization?  Well, if this review doesn’t help you decide, then I wish you best of luck in finding a better place to continue your career.  I would like to take this opportunity to say “thank you” to Ultimate Medical Academy for being so accommodating and being that “Ultimate” employer!
featuredReview.cons: Nothing in this world is perfect. But at this time this part is not applicable.

featuredReview.headline: A Great Place to Work with a Pay-It-Forward Culture
featuredReview.pros: I have worked for SNC for 8+ years and have always been attracted by the family culture the owners, Eren and Fatih have created within a large company. In many aspects it feels like a small close knit company. They are generous to their employees with the high level of benefits including the 401k match, bonuses, and medical insurance. They are also generous and have a heartfelt compassion to help those in need, albeit employees experiencing a family crisis or victims of natural disasters, including the recent hurricane relief effort of $1M, offering matching contributions to the amount raised by the employees. They don't do this out of obligation, but they do these things because of who they are.  I am blessed to have the opportunity to work for Sierra Nevada. The work is gratifying, the people I work with are great, and the work that we do is important.  Eren and Fatih have a generous and compassionate heart and are making the world a better place.
featuredReview.cons: I would like to see a Roth 401k option

featuredReview.headline: Great place, not great for me long-term
featuredReview.pros:
* Not difficult to start and train in. 

* Nice experience to have, working around pleasant food, fruit, chocolate. Nicer than some alternatives like french fries and hamburgers!

* Depending on where you work, very friendly people to talk to. The radio can be on if no one is on the phone.

* Flexible hours.
featuredReview.cons:
* Not a lot of room for growth or advancement, outside of something like becoming a store manager.

* During slow periods the hours can dry up. Store owner sometimes requested that store manager cut some people loose for the day.

The above is really the only reason I left, as I wanted to work full-time somewhere with consistent hours and a little more pay.

featuredReview.headline: Hurricane Harvey relief efforts are our priority
featuredReview.pros:
Not only does #alliantgroup help American Businesses find government sponsored incentives, we come together to help demo/rebuild homes that were damaged in #HurricaneHarvey. I'm so proud of my family and the work they did this weekend helping our own!!! 
Big hearted Dhaval Jadav and Shane Frank coordinated all efforts and worked amongst a group of volunteers on several  of our employees homes affected by Hurricane Harvey. I know this is just the beginning to help the Houston community rebuild and I can't wait to be apart of what is to come. I'm so fortunate to be a part of this #blueateam.  #HoustonStrong #10yearsofgoodness
featuredReview.cons: There's so much to do for our #Houston community and I'm disappointed that I'm not there. Can't wait to be able to assist this weekend.

featuredReview.headline: Keeping it Real!
featuredReview.pros:
My reasons for truly loving my job,
We have a very committed leadership team. We foster a bought in mentality.
We don't always get it right, however there is always a leader willing to help pick you up and dust you off. I have never been made to feel less than by anyone here. We believe in embracing change and moving foward. We invest in our future, hiring bright up and coming managers who are willing to learn and get stronger. I am a current 
General Manager for RMH and a proud Pride of the Hive member! 6 years right around the corner!
featuredReview.cons: This is a real job accountable to guests, employees and yes believe it or not the bottom line. We are in business to make a profit and that requires hard work , dedication and passion. If you are not willing to get in here and do your best don't come here because we have standards and we hold our selves up to them. Once again we don't always get it right but we learn from it and move on.

featuredReview.headline: Good pay in one-piece

featuredReview.cons: Incentive to grade well and make a LOT more money is restricted by seniority taking precedence over performance grades and constant new hires. If you stick around awhile until your bunch of new hires leaves or gets the boot, and you are catching on, you can look forward to higher pay within a few years if you can grade well and earn it.

featuredReview.headline: Tech Support at Tableau
featuredReview.pros: Absolutely amazing coworkers, excellent immediate managers. Expectations were reasonable and I always felt that management was on my side. While I was there we had pretty high turn-over because of the low pay, but they recently gave a huge raise to everyone in tech support right before I left, which mostly fixed this issue. Good training program for Tableau products. Great benefits, free food, good culture. Its clear that Tableau as a company cares a lot about its employees. While I was there it definitely had some growing pains while it was maturing into the large company it is now. I didn't leave because I didn't like Tableau, its just the job wasn't for me.
featuredReview.cons: There wasn't a lot of training for non-Tableau products, which became an issue as our customers became more sophisticated. Advancement path was not always very clear and there were limited opportunities for people in tech support to move to other roles within the company. Not very many women/minorities in leadership positions.

featuredReview.headline: Family intervention Specialist
featuredReview.pros: You make good connections with clients and feel like you have made a difference. The annual Employee conference is nice.
featuredReview.cons:
On call rotation is a nightmare. You don't get paid for being on call 24/7 once a week every month. You do pointless check-ins with clients who are not in crisis. Which defeats the whole purpose of it.
Paperwork is tedious and REDUNDANT. You fill out the exact same information under multiple tabs, in multiple rows, on multiple documents - day after day, after day ---weeks, months in a row.
Upper management adds new expectations, tasks, meetings every week just for the heck of it. (It's always has to be something that staff is doing "wrong" or "bad")
Driving radius to clients is way too far.
You'll need a new car after driving around as much as you do in this position if you stay longer then a year. Expect lots of miles on your car, maintenance,
and minimal compensation.
Prepare to be forced to go into unsafe situations/neighborhoods with no support or concern about your safety. "Families first"..definitely not you or YOUR own family. Self-care is not prioritized or promoted. You feel like you can't take off because of guilt and someone will have to cover your caseload.

featuredReview.headline: Account Executive
featuredReview.pros:
1. Culture- The culture and the company's training  and development are my biggest pros. The balance between enjoying work and working hard at the St. Louis office is makes it an ideal place to build a career with. The office manager really sets this in motion and it was obvious that it trickles down with everyone else. 

2. Training-  I didn't have a strong understanding of the  3PL and Freight industry  before PLS's training. PLS uses a multi-prong approach:  class room, experiential, and mentoring to teach their trainees everything they need to know about the industry before they start talking with customers and carriers. That helped alot.

3. Opportunities to Grow-  I could see that PLS is a company that values promoting from within.  I noticed that they emphasized positions in other parts of the company to current PLS employees.
featuredReview.cons: The freight industry starts a little earlier than the traditional 9-5.

featuredReview.headline: Truly a great place to work!
featuredReview.pros: I can say that they have the BEST medical/dental/vision insurance policies of any organization where I've worked, in Memphis.  The Administration at SJ really wants all employees to have work/life balance.  To assist employees with this, they have a first class gym, on campus, with free membership to all employees.  They offer group exercise programs or, you may choose to take an afternoon bike ride with other employees.  And, the best surprise of all, we will occasionally receive "additional" days off on major holidays.  Since Christmas is on a Monday this year (2017) we were also given the Friday prior as an additional holiday.  And, they just increased the amount of vacation you get!
featuredReview.cons: Wow, I cannot think of any cons about working at SJ.  When I first began working at SJ, it sometimes would upset me if I saw a sick child.  Now, after fully understanding the mission and seeing the ongoing efforts the doctors and researchers, I know SJ is the BEST place for the children facing these challenges.

While each department is different, my experience on the tech floor was very lively. It's not uncommon to be interrupted by a ringing bell and a cake of some sort to celebrate a birthday or anniversary.  Conversations about tech or someone's weekend plans will be happening around you. An impromptu nerf gun fight might take place. Of course, that's not to say that work doesn't get done. featuredReview.headline: If you are looking for a sign, THIS IS IT!

featuredReview.headline: One of the best places I've ever worked....
featuredReview.pros:
- The SKILL of the workers who make these products that enhance people's lives is amazing.  Many are long-term employees who've only worked at Smith & Nephew, and retire there.
- The culture really worked for me - when I interviewed, I'll never forget that people waved and spoke to me as I was touring.
- The work was crazy busy, but the pay was great and I felt very invested in the the success of the company.  I felt proud to work for a company that made the products that they make, and it made a difference in my level of dedication.
featuredReview.cons: My area of responsibility was very broad at the time, and there was so ground to cover that I couldn't implement my (own personal) vision/culture as I wanted, but that's to be expected with any busy company.  Eventually the structure changed, and I've heard that things are much more manageable.  This is one of the signs of a good company.

featuredReview.headline: Work here if you want to make an impact
featuredReview.pros: If you want to make an impact, Elsevier is the kind of place that lets you push beyond limits, beyond your job description, beyond your "rank" in the company. Initiative is welcomed here.  Employees who identify a problem or a challenge can  form coalitions, devise solutions, and get things done.   Elsevier is a truly global company.  You work with people of all nationalities in multiple locations.   And because of that, you gain a wide perspective that informs  your daily work and decisions.  Elsevier is at a stage in its storied history where it is moving far beyond it's publishing heritage.  Advances in data science and machine learning now make it possible to extract intelligence and insight from Elsevier's trove of data and highly structured information.  Certainly every big company today is becoming a "big-data company" but in Elsevier's case, there is a potential  to advance science and health and contribute an extraordinary impact.   The people at Elsevier around the world are well-educated, engaged, dedicated, and care deeply about what they do.  You rarely come across anybody just punching the clock here.      It's exciting to be a part of this.
featuredReview.cons: Elsevier has a long history and with that comes a fantastic foundation of content, data, and operational expertise; but it also comes with baggage. legacy systems, legacy policies, and bureaucracy are the norm for well-established companies and Elsevier is no different in that regard.   But when you make that breakthrough, or cross that milestone at Elsevier, it's all the more satisfying to see the difference you are making , and the difference that the company can make.   It's tougher to make a career for employees outside our corporate centers.  The onus is on you to build you network (often virtual) and gain visibility.   Elsevier demands a great deal of its employees. International collaboration also comes with crazy work hours.  Those who are strong at self-managing themselves will do well here.   Those who are waiting for a job description and what to do will have a tough time.

featuredReview.headline: Avalon puts as much effort into employee satisfaction as they do the customer.  (that's rare!)

Avalon does too, but takes it a step further by ensuring the employee is happy and has everything he/she needs to grow and succeed in their position.  People above and around me, with more experience,  go out of their way on a regular basis to assist me as I learn my way.  My work is hard, it is stressful and at times chaotic, but I never wake up in the morning and think "I hate my job".  I made a career change to be here, and left a miserable work life behind me. I have ZERO regrets and I'm thankful I stumbled upon AvalonBay.
featuredReview.cons: More extensive training, possibly a online course/tutorial, for the new database software.  It took me quite a while to settle in.

Great company who has strong national presence but allows substantial control at the state and branch levels.  Not a lot of red tape!  I am often complimented for owning such a great company who delivers a great experience to the clients and realtors to which I reply that I wish I owned Academy.  With more than 300 branches nationwide, it's pretty cool that anyone sees that we have great control locally.  

Academy is all about the people.  They constantly invest in their people.  One evening at 6pm I receive a call from Adam Kessler, the CEO.  He was calling to get my opinion on how things were going.  Pretty incredible.

featuredReview.headline: 13-yr-old Startup
featuredReview.pros:
The best thing about InsideSales.com is the business model.  Access to proprietary sales interaction data--anonymized--and then a way to monetize that data by using it to help other customers sell more?  It may be the greatest business model ever.

Second best is the people, but this hasn't consistently been true.  The people at InsideSales today are True Believers, and they are working hard to make the vision for the company come true.

I appreciate a startup culture.  In a startup, there isn't time for politics, and the only thing that matters is results.  InsideSales felt that way in the early days, then forgot it was a startup and hired bureaucrats and corporate survivors.  These hiring mis-steps almost cost InsideSales its birthright, and the startup soul of the company was nearly sucked out.

But...  the bureaucrats and cynics are gone, the startup culture is back, and things are up and to the right again.

No startup is without its drama or existential risk.  InsideSales has both, and it is an invigorating place to work!
featuredReview.cons:
InsideSales still has a couple of cultural hangovers.  One is a "blame culture," which might stem from the bad experience of having too many bureaucrats and corporate survivors in management.  But we need to continue to squash that.  Good people are doing their best to fight battles every day, and we need to support them in their successes and failures.

The other thing we don't have right yet is a true focus on customer success.  This is especially true of the product organization.  Product is becoming more customer empathetic, but they aren't there yet.  It can still be the case that engineers or PMs cite internal considerations as reasons not to do the right thing for the customer.  Or worse yet, not bother to find out what the customer needs.  This is moving in the right direction, but we are not there yet.  Customer success needs to be front and center!

Don't get it twisted this job will stress you out, your loved ones will try to give you advice but they have no idea. Oh, and even though they offered you $21 an hour its more live $17.19 because they take money for an 'SCA rate????!!!' which you never get back. featuredReview.headline: Seasonal positions with NPS
featuredReview.pros:
- You have the chance to intimately know some of the most meaningful natural, historic, and cultural places in the country
- You will work with generally reasonable, intelligent, and passionate folks who share similar interests
- If you are a student or recent grad, it is a great experience to build your resume
featuredReview.cons:
- Salary is not commensurate to your education/experience for a seasonal job, even though it's still very competitive (lots of qualified people want to work for NPS).
- Park housing is cheap, but you get what you pay for--most of it is old and in need of some type of repair, but there's just not a sufficient maintenance budget. Same with offices--most are old buildings that really aren't designed for their current staff/use.
- It's really , really difficult to obtain a permanent job with this agency.  My advice to job seekers is to do seasonal jobs at first, but be open to other opportunities (state parks, non-profits, other government jobs). If your heart is truly set on working permanently for NPS, you're either going to be disappointed, or have to sacrifice a lot.
